subject: Re: [junit] Re: Missing API: Assert.assertThat(boolean) or 	IsCollection.isEmpty()
msgSnippet: ... equalTo was just an example.  It could be greaterThan or any other matcher. The difference between assertThat and your example is that assertThat could
messageBody:
2009/5/20 Cédric Beust ♔ <cbeust@...>:
> On Tue, May 19, 2009 at 3:50 PM, Nat Pryce <nat.pryce@...> wrote:
>> As for objects that return a non-boolean result, there could (maybe,
>> not sure how) be a three-parameter version like:
>>
>> assertThat(list, theAforementioned(List.class).size()).is(equalTo(0)));
>
> Am I the only one finding that this is awfully convoluted compared to
>
> assertEquals(0, list.size());

equalTo was just an example. It could be greaterThan or any other matcher.

The difference between assertThat and your example is that assertThat
could generate a meaningful error message describing what was being
matched, because the automagical reflection would capture that "size"
is being called, while assertEquals cannot.

But yes, the API as described is a bit rubbish. As David said, the
names would need to be improved.

--Nat
